items.title: View deleted instances from admin page
items.body: The `SimpleHistoryAdmin` allows the history of a instance that still exists to bee seen. It would be great if there would be a way to view a list of deleted instances, and see their histories.

items.title: Improve DockerCompose documentation
items.body:
Hi. I'm starting to use testcontainers to test the behavior of a simple P2P network written in Python. I noticed that the auto-generated documentation for each class is just a copy of the constructor (without parameters descriptions) and a small code example. It would be really helpful if, at least, a small description of the behavior of each available method for each class was provided. Then this could be improved by adding a small description of the meaning of each parameter.

Small addition: for some reason, the [documentation](https://testcontainers-python.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html) has really big margins on the left and the right but the title is too long.
![Screenshot (113)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68538713/145970985-5328c562-716b-4ca7-9c55-31583372ba6a.png)

items.title: mypy does not recognize __qualname__

labels.name: bug
labels.description: mypy got something wrong

labels.name: false-positive
labels.description: mypy gave an error on correct code

labels.name: topic-runtime-semantics
labels.description: mypy doesn't model runtime semantics correctly

items.body:
1. Given Python file `test1.py`
```Python
class A(object):
    NAME = __qualname__
```
2. run mypy checking

       mypy test1.py

3. **_BUG:_** mypy reports `not defined`

       test1.py:2: error: Name '__qualname__' is not defined

The Python interpreter runs the code without error.

`__qualname__` has [been available since Python 3.3](https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#definition.__qualname__).

Tested on _Python 3.7.1_, using _mpypy 0.670_.

items.title: /NoRegistry and /NoShortcuts options for installer not written in the docs

labels.name: source::community
labels.description: catch-all for issues filed by community members

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: great for new contributors, code change is envisioned to be trivial/relatively straight-forward

labels.name: type::installer
labels.description: indicates a request or issue pertaining to the installer

labels.name: type::documentation
labels.description: request for improved documentation

labels.name: backlog
labels.description: issue has been triaged but has not been earmarked for any upcoming release

items.body:
### Checklist

- [X] I added a descriptive title
- [X] I searched for other issues and couldn't find a solution or duplication
- [X] I already searched in Google and didn't find any good information or help
- [X] I looked at the [docs](https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda/en/latest/user-guide/index.html) and didn't see anything to help

### What happened?

/NoRegistry and /NoShortcuts options for installer is not written in the docs. I was able to find them in the issues but not in the docs.

- /NoRegistry
  - https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/1977
  - https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/10585
- /NoShortcuts
  - https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/7507
  - https://github.com/conda/constructor/issues/452
  - https://github.com/conda/constructor/pull/466

### Conda info

```shell
It's about documentation
```


### Conda config

```shell
It's about documentation
```


### Conda list

_No response_

### Additional Context

There are new features being included over the years but I find many of them are not properly included in the docs. IMO proper documentation should be addressed for developers who make pull requests and manage merging

items.title: [gh-pages] Update RADI launch commands after dockerfile refactoring

labels.name: gh-pages
labels.description: Github Pages

items.body:
New commands are:

- Standard launch:
```
docker run -it --rm -p <ports> jderobot/robotics-academy
```

- GPU acceleration launch:
```
docker run -it --rm --device /dev/dri -p <ports> jderobot/robotics-academy
```

- Store terminal output launch:
```
docker run -it --rm -v $HOME/.roboticsacademy/log/:/root/.roboticsacademy/log/ -p <ports> jderobot/robotics-academy --logs
```

Notice that list of used ports may vary depending on the exercise.

items.title: Fix typos in the docs - multiple PRs welcome!

labels.name: outreachy-task
labels.description: Starter tasks for the Outreachy program

items.body:
**From https://github.com/MDAnalysis/UserGuide/issues/194 -- @micaela-matta**

This issue is designed to be incrementally achieved through multiple PRs. 

There are a few typos in the user guide, this issue will collect as many as we can find starting with the short list below.
Feel free to fix any typos/formatting errors we haven't noticed and add them in the comments!

- units and conversions [page]( https://docs.mdanalysis.org/2.1.0-dev0/documentation_pages/units.html?highlight=unit%20conversion#conversions), note box: "in the future me might" 
- units and conversions [page]( https://docs.mdanalysis.org/2.1.0-dev0/documentation_pages/units.html?highlight=unit%20conversion#conversions), above the note box: fix LaTeX formatting for `rho/rho0 = n/(N_A * M**-1) / rho0 where [n] = 1/Volume, [rho] = mass/Volume`
- units and conversions [page]( https://docs.mdanalysis.org/2.1.0-dev0/documentation_pages/units.html?highlight=unit%20conversion#conversions), `MDAnalysis.units.water`: fix scientific notation in`and molar mass 18.016 g mol**-1`
- density analysis [page](https://docs.mdanalysis.org/2.1.0-dev0/documentation_pages/analysis/density.html), units and conversions [page]https://docs.mdanalysis.org/2.1.0-dev0/documentation_pages/units.html?highlight=unit%20conversion#conversions) (and probably many other pages): the symbol `Ã…`  appears many times in different formats (`Ã¥ngstrÃ¶ms`, `Ã…**-3`, `Angstroms` etc). Depending on the context in the page, keep LaTeX equation style or replace with the standard symbol `Ã…` and correct scientific notation.

items.title: In teacher view, only the teacher's last name is displayed in the top header.
mypy Type error for a class with an imported metaclass

labels.name: bug
labels.description: mypy got something wrong

labels.name: false-positive
labels.description: mypy gave an error on correct code

items.body:
Please provide more information to help us understand the issue:

* Are you reporting a bug, or opening a feature request? bug
* Please insert below the code you are checking with mypy,
  or a mock-up repro if the source is private. We would appreciate
  if you try to simplify your case to a minimal repro.
Here is an example class I am working with.
```
@enum.unique
class MyEnumClass(Enum, metaclass=MyEnumMetaClass):
    OUT_OF_STOCK = "Out of Stock"
    LOW_STOCK = "Low Stock"
    IN_STOCK = "In Stock"
    EXCESS = "Excess"
```

I am making a change where I am importing the `MyEnumMetaClass` class from a PIP package now, whereas before it was located within the same project as this class. 

* What is the actual behavior/output?
With `MyEnumMetaClass` imported, whenever I create a `MyEnumClass` instance, mypy gives me the following error:
`error: The type "Type[MyEnumClass]" is not generic and not indexable`
* What is the behavior/output you expect?
I expect mypy to succeed here, given that the code is the same, it is just imported from a package now.

items.title: mypy --strict has misleading suggestion for Callable

labels.name: bug
labels.description: mypy got something wrong

labels.name: topic-configuration
labels.description: Configuration files and flags

labels.name: topic-error-reporting
labels.description: How we report errors

items.body:
<!--
  If you're new to mypy and you're not sure whether what you're experiencing is a mypy bug, please see the "Question and Help" form
  instead.
  Please also consider:

  - checking our common issues page: https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/common_issues.html
  - searching our issue tracker: https://github.com/python/mypy/issues to see if
    it's already been reported
  - asking on gitter chat: https://gitter.im/python/typing
-->

**Bug Report**

<!--
Note: If the problem you are reporting is about a specific library function, then the typeshed tracker is better suited
for this report: https://github.com/python/typeshed/issues
-->

It's not a big issue, not sure if you should even qualify it as a bug but I fought it fitted better than other categories.
When in strict mode, it gives a suggestion that is actually not valid in strict mode.

**To Reproduce**

Running `mypy --strict` on this code
```
from typing import Callable

def my_function(callback: Callable[...]) -> None:
    callback()
```
gives the following error message:
```
$ mypy callable_test.py --strict
callable_test.py:3: error: Please use "Callable[[<parameters>], <return type>]" or "Callable"        
Found 1 error in 1 file (checked 1 source file)
```

However, changing the code to use the second suggestion of using `Callable`:
```
from typing import Callable

def my_function(callback: Callable) -> None:
    callback()
```
gives a new error message:

```
$ mypy callable_test.py --strict
callable_test.py:3: error: Missing type parameters for generic type "Callable"
Found 1 error in 1 file (checked 1 source file)
```

Running mypy in non-strict mode does not give this error. But if it is at all possible it would be nice to remove the second suggestion in strict mode (or turn it into `Callable[..., Any]`).

I got confused (didn't spot that I was missing an `Any` return value in my `Callable[...]` annotation) and kept switching back and forth wondering why the suggestion was not working. Which admittedly is my mistake. But it did bring to light for me that the suggestion is a bit misleading in this context.

I don't know if this is easily done or not, if it's a relatively minor fix I'd be willing to give it a crack.


Additional info:
```
$ mypy --version
mypy 0.902
```
```
$ python --version
Python 3.8.10
```

items.title: mypy generates `__match_args__` for dataclasses and `NamedTuple`s on Python <3.10

labels.name: bug
labels.description: mypy got something wrong

labels.name: topic-match-statement
labels.description: Python 3.10's match statement

labels.name: topic-runtime-semantics
labels.description: mypy doesn't model runtime semantics correctly

items.body:
**Bug Report**

Not a big deal, but mypy appears to generate `__match_args__` for dataclasses and `NamedTuple`s even when running with `--python-version` set to 3.9:

```python
from dataclasses import dataclass
from typing import NamedTuple

@dataclass
class One:
    bar: int

f: One
reveal_type(f.__match_args__)  # Revealed type is "Tuple[Literal['bar']]"

class Two(NamedTuple):
    baz: str

g: Two
reveal_type(g.__match_args__)  # Revealed type is "Tuple[Literal['baz']]"
```

**Expected Behavior**

Mypy should not autogenerate `__match_args__` when running with `--python-version` set to <3.10, as pattern-matching is new in 3.10.

**Your Environment**

- Mypy version used: `0.950+dev.a33d2353a81d075850a487f3913720037f2473aa (compiled: no)`
- Mypy command-line flags: `--python-version 3.9`
- Mypy configuration options from `mypy.ini` (and other config files): None
- Python version used: 3.10
- Operating system and version: Windows

items.title: Update FAQ
items.body:
If you have encountered any problems while working with MDAnalysis, and you do not see the problem and solution on the MDAnalysis FAQ (https://userguide.mdanalysis.org/stable/faq.html), please help us update our documentation by opening a pull request! The contribution should consist of:

* a heading summarising the problem or question
* (Optionally) more detail about the problem, possibly with examples or error messages
* An answer or solution. You don't need to come up with this yourself! Please email the MDAnalysis mailing list (https://groups.google.com/group/mdnalysis-discussion) or open an issue at the main repository (https://github.com/MDAnalysis/mdanalysis/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aopen+sort%3Aupdated-desc) if you need help.

The user guide contains a section on contributing here: https://userguide.mdanalysis.org/stable/contributing_docs.html

items.title: RFE: Excluded paths

labels.name: feature
labels.description: New feature or a request for enhancement.

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: Good for newcomers.

labels.name: triaged
labels.description: This issue was already processed by the team.

labels.name: user-experience
labels.description: Usability issue.

items.body:
For people who are running monorepos it would be helpful if we can define excluded paths. Basically Packit wouldn't be running on top of PRs where changes are happening only in excluded paths.

This is what you can define with GitHub Actions.
```
on:
  pull_request:
    paths-ignore:
    - 'docs/**'
```  

You don't want to waste computation and waiting for RPMs which you don't need at all.
Later on, this may be extended even to branches.

You can find more how GitHub handles this in [GitHub Actions docs](https://help.github.com/en/actions/reference/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#onpushpull_requestpaths)

items.title: Clean up arrays memory handling flags

labels.name: internals
labels.description: Pyccel's internal behavior, does not affect user experience

items.body:
There are 3 types of arrays:
- pointers
- stack arrays
- allocatables

These 3 options are mutually exclusive. E.g. an object cannot be both a pointer and allocatable. One of these 3 options must always be set to `True` (otherwise the array cannot be declared except in the case of an argument, which can be treated like a stack array).

This is obvious to developers familiar with Fortran, however from a C perspective it is less clear. In order to avoid bugs I propose that we enforce these rules by storing a string in an attribute `Variable._memory_handling` which can only have one of the following values: `pointer`, `stack_array`, `allocatable`.

This issue was created following confusion in PR [#1056](https://github.com/pyccel/pyccel/pull/1056#discussion_r820478765)

items.title: TST, MAINT: modernizing Encore tests with `np.all()`
items.body:
There are a few issues with the Encore tests in `testsuite/MDAnalysisTests/analysis/test_encore.py `. One that stands out is the usage of `assert np.all()`, which gives inferior failure reports compared to `assert_allclose()` et al.

Consider:

```python
In [2]: arr = np.array([1, 2, 3])

In [3]: assert np.all(arr == [1, 2, 4])
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AssertionError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-08a34a54ff2a> in <module>
----> 1 assert np.all(arr == [1, 2, 4])

AssertionError: 

In [4]: from numpy.testing import assert_allclose

In [5]: assert_allclose(arr, [1, 2, 4])
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AssertionError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-5-f488012b8860> in <module>
----> 1 assert_allclose(arr, [1, 2, 4])

    [... skipping hidden 1 frame]

~/python_venvs/python_395/lib/python3.9/site-packages/numpy/testing/_private/utils.py in assert_array_compare(comparison, x, y, err_msg, verbose, header, precision, equal_nan, equal_inf)
    842                                 verbose=verbose, header=header,
    843                                 names=('x', 'y'), precision=precision)
--> 844             raise AssertionError(msg)
    845     except ValueError:
    846         import traceback

AssertionError: 
Not equal to tolerance rtol=1e-07, atol=0

Mismatched elements: 1 / 3 (33.3%)
Max absolute difference: 1
Max relative difference: 0.25
 x: array([1, 2, 3])
 y: array([1, 2, 4])

```

<!-- A clear and concise description of what you want to do and what you think should happen. (Code to reproduce the behavior can be added below). -->

Sub-issue of #760

Doc examples work.


## Actual behavior ##

<!-- What happened instead. Add as much detail as you can. Include (copy and paste) stack traces and any output. -->

This is after changing a `>>>` in the rotation matrix example to `...`

```
================================================== FAILURES ===================================================

Got:

UNEXPECTED EXCEPTION: NameError("name 'A' is not defined")
Traceback (most recent call last):

    compileflags, 1), test.globs)
```

``` python
import MDAnalysis as mda
from MDAnalysis.tests.datafiles import PSF, DCD,  GRO, PDB, TPR, XTC, TRR,  PRMncdf, NCDF

u = mda.Universe(PSF, DCD)
```

- Which version of Python (`python -V`)? 3.7.3
- Which operating system? Mac Catalina

items.title: DeprecationWarnings: numpy - elementwise comparison, calling nonzero on 0d arrays, `np.object`.
items.body:
Couple of numpy deprecation warnings we'll need to take care of.

This gets thrown in `hbond_autocorrel.py`:

```
hbond_autocorrel.py:435: DeprecationWarning: elementwise comparison failed; this will raise an error in the future.
    pair = np.delete(pair, np.where(pair==exclude), 0)
```

This gets throws in `test_hydrogenbond_autocorrel_deprecated.py`:

```
<__array_function__ internals>:180: DeprecationWarning: Calling nonzero on 0d arrays is deprecated, as it behaves surprisingly. Use `atleast_1d(cond).nonzero()` if the old behavior was intended. If the context of this warning is of the form `arr[nonzero(cond)]`, just use `arr[cond]`.
```

This deprecation warning gets thrown in `test_topologyattr.py`:

```
DeprecationWarning: `np.object` is a deprecated alias for the builtin `object`. To silence this warning, use `object` by itself. Doing this will not modify any behavior and is safe.
  Deprecated in NumPy 1.20; for more details and guidance: https://numpy.org/devdocs/release/1.20.0-notes.html#deprecations
    dtype=np.object)
```

MDA version: 2.1.0-dev0

items.title: Recognize platform.system() as well as sys.platform is

labels.name: topic-runtime-semantics
labels.description: mypy doesn't model runtime semantics correctly

items.body:
Note: if you are reporting a wrong signature of a function or a class in
the standard library, then the typeshed tracker is better suited
for this report: https://github.com/python/typeshed/issues

Please provide more information to help us understand the issue:

* Are you reporting a bug, or opening a feature request? feature request
* Please insert below the code you are checking with mypy,
  or a mock-up repro if the source is private. We would appreciate
  if you try to simplify your case to a minimal repro.
```python
    if platform.system() != "Windows":  # sys.platform != "win32":
        try:
            # os.confstr("CS_GNU_LIBC_VERSION") returns a string like "glibc 2.17".
            version_string = os.confstr("CS_GNU_LIBC_VERSION")
            assert version_string is not None
            _, version = version_string.split()
        except (AssertionError, OSError, ValueError):
            # os.confstr() or CS_GNU_LIBC_VERSION not available (or a bad value)...
            return None
        return version
    return None
```
* What is the actual behavior/output? "error: Module has no attribute "confstr""
* What is the behavior/output you expect? No error when run under Windows
* What are the versions of mypy and Python you are using? mypy 0.750, Python 3.7.4

Basically it would be nice to get to use `platform.system()` instead of having to use `sys.platform` to make mypy happy with code that is conditional on the platform.

items.title: Better error location for incompatible override due to argument incompatibility

labels.name: topic-inheritance
labels.description: Inheritance and incompatible overrides

labels.name: topic-error-reporting
labels.description: How we report errors

items.body:
An incompatible override gets reported on the first line of a method header, even though it would be better to point it at the line with an argument that is incompatible, when possible. Example:

```py
class A:
    def f(self, x: int, y: str, z: float) -> None: pass

class B(A):
    def f(  # Argument 3 incompatible with supertype "A" <-- reported here
            self,
            x: int,
            y: str,
            z: bool,  # <-- would be better to report it here
    ) -> None:
        pass
```

This would improve usability, especially for methods with many arguments on many lines. This would also make it cleaner to ignore these errors, as the location of the `# type: ignore` comment would document which argument is incompatible (if there is one argument per line, which is a common convention).

items.title: Protocol documentation for arguments is misleading
items.body:
Very happy to be using protocols. One small note, in the documentation here:

https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/protocols.html#callback-protocols

`Keyword argument names in __call__ methods must be identical, unless a double underscore prefix is used`

Really, I think this should say "Arguments" and not "Keyword" arguments. Unless I'm missing something, this applies to *all* argument names, not just keyword ones.

items.title: Friendlier error when 3.10 is parsed as float in pyproject.toml

labels.name: bug
labels.description: mypy got something wrong

labels.name: topic-error-reporting
labels.description: How we report errors

items.body:
**Bug Report**

<!--
Note: If the problem you are reporting is about a specific library function, then the typeshed tracker is better suited
for this report: https://github.com/python/typeshed/issues
-->

Running mypy with Python 3.10 and `python_version` in the config file has a few wrong behaviors:
1. It lists mypy must be 3.4 or higher (it should say 3.6)
2. It truncates Python 3.10 to 3.1
3. It outputs a message when there shouldn't be one (you can invoke mypy with Python 3.10)

**To Reproduce**

Here is a subset of my `pyproject.toml`:

```toml
[tool.mypy]
# SEE: http://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config_file.html#config-file

# Specifies the Python version used to parse and check the target program.
python_version = 3.10

# Enables PEP 420 style namespace packages.
namespace_packages = true
```

I invoke mypy via: `mypy -p namespacepkg`

**Expected Behavior**

<!--
  How did you expect your project to behave?
  Itâ€™s fine if youâ€™re not sure your understanding is correct.
  Write down what you thought would happen. If you just expected no errors, you can delete this section.
-->

Not to raise this message.

**Actual Behavior**

<!--
  Did something go wrong?
  Is something broken, or not behaving as you expected?
-->

```
pyproject.toml: [mypy]: python_version: Python 3.1 is not supported (must be 3.4 or higher)
```

**Your Environment**

<!-- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->

- Mypy version used: 0.931
- Mypy command-line flags: n/a
- Mypy configuration options from `mypy.ini` (and other config files): see above `pyproject.toml`
- Python version used: 3.10.2
- Operating system and version: macOS v11.5.1 Big Sur

<!--
You can freely edit this text, please remove all the lines
you believe are unnecessary.
-->

items.title: Require an annotation if inferred list or dict item type is object

labels.name: topic-join-v-union
labels.description: Using join vs. using unions

items.body:
Mypy infers the type `List[object]` for `x` in this example:

```py
x = [1, 'a']
```

This is often not what the user expects and can be confusing, as there tends to be an error when the program tries to do something with the list. Often the user would prefer the type to be `List[Any]` or `List[Union[int, str]]`, but generally the desired item type could be something else, such as an ABC or protocol (once protocols are supported).

It's perhaps impractical to unambiguously infer the desired type, but it would be easy enough to detect cases like these and require an explicit annotation. For the above example, mypy would require an annotation for `x` (and potentially suggest `List[Any]` or `List[Union[int, str]]` as the potential type), similar to how mypy deals with `x = []`. 

For user-defined generic types `object` might be a reasonable value for a type parameter, so we should probably restrict this to things where the `object` type is likely a problem. For example, we could generate the message for the types `List[object]` and `Dict[<anything>, object]` only. It's less clear if we should do this for dictionaries with`object` keys or for sets.

items.title: TypeVars should be allowed to be the same
items.body:
Two unbound TypeVars `A` and `B` can potentially be the same:

```py
from typing import Callable, Iterable, TypeVar

A = TypeVar("A")
B = TypeVar("B")

def identity(x: A) -> A:
    return x

# ok
def _map(queue: Iterable[B], function: Callable[[B], A]) -> Iterable[A]:
    return map(function, queue)

# fails
def _map2(queue: Iterable[B], function: Callable[[B], A] = identity) -> Iterable[A]:
    return map(function, queue)
```

The introduced default keyword argument leads to the following unexpected error:
`error: Incompatible default for argument "function" (default has type "Callable[[A], A]", argument has type "Callable[[B], A]")`

I'm using mypy 0.740.

items.title: Privacy dialog doesn't display the current settings for share photo/schedule
Add favicon.ico

items.title: Fix cropping for photos
items.body: The aspect ratio for photos is different this year, and the default crop cuts off the top of heads. We should adjust the crop logic in `cron/update_photos.py` to use a different crop for this aspect ratio.

items.title: [ENH] BiphasicPulseTrain metadata
items.body:
Currently, manipulating `BiphasicPulseTrains` results in unexpected behavior when using with a `BiphasicAxonMapModel`. During creation, the amplitude, frequency, and pulse duration are stored in metadata, and are later used in the `BiphasicAxonMapModel`. If  pulse train is modified in any way (e.g. multiplying by a scaler to scale amplitude), the metadata is unchanged, and the model will predict the same thing.

If this were updated, then `ImageStimulus` would be able to be used with amplitude encoding


**Describe the solution you'd like**
Modifying a `BiphasicPulseTrain` should either update the metadata if the resulting pulse is still a valid `BiphasicPulseTrain`, or it should somehow mark in the metadata that this is no longer a valid `BiphasicPulseTrain` so that the Biphasic model will reject the stimulus. The overloaded [operaters](https://github.com/pulse2percept/pulse2percept/blob/a4fcea1ccb63703b0f8baee150a551d73ec2f7b8/pulse2percept/stimuli/base.py#L711-L750) will have to be overridden for `BiphasicPulseTrain`, and perhaps some metadata changes.

items.title: [ENH] A global delay for BiphasicPulseTrain
items.body: Currently delay_dur is considered as a part of each cycle. We cannot create a BiphasicPulseTrain with a global delay. Might be good to have that as well.

items.title: 'in' operator rejected with union right operand

labels.name: bug
labels.description: mypy got something wrong

labels.name: false-positive
labels.description: mypy gave an error on correct code

items.body:
Mypy generates a false positive for this fragment:

```py
from typing import Iterable, Container, Union

i: Iterable[str]
c: Container[str]
u: Union[Iterable[str], Container[str]]

'x' in i
'x' in c
'x' in u  # Unsupported right operand type for in ("Union[Iterable[str], Container[str]]")
```

This should be easy to fix.

items.title: Generate better error message for incompatible **kwargs

labels.name: topic-calls
labels.description: Function calls, *args, **kwargs, defaults

items.body:
This output is from #8772:

```
$ mypy test.py 
test.py:6: error: Argument 2 to "dumps" has incompatible type "**Dict[str, int]"; expected "bool"
test.py:6: error: Argument 2 to "dumps" has incompatible type "**Dict[str, int]"; expected "Optional[Type[JSONEncoder]]"
test.py:6: error: Argument 2 to "dumps" has incompatible type "**Dict[str, int]"; expected "Optional[Tuple[str, str]]"
test.py:6: error: Argument 2 to "dumps" has incompatible type "**Dict[str, int]"; expected "Optional[Callable[[Any], Any]]"
Found 4 errors in 1 file (checked 1 source file)
```

The error messages are pretty confusing. We should special case this and produce a customized error message that explains the situation better.

Here's the code that triggers the errors:

```py
import json

json_kwargs = dict(indent=2)

json.dumps({}, **json_kwargs)
```

Some ideas about what to do:
* Generate a single error message instead of multiple ones.
* Add a note suggesting the use of `Dict[str, Any]` or a TypedDict type for the `**kwargs` argument.
* Maybe also explain that mypy matches the value type against all arguments, or add a link to documentation (add something to common issues, for example).

items.title: bug: ec2 describe-availability-zones with --zone-name returns all zones

labels.name: good-first-issue
labels.description: Good item to work on for newcomers

labels.name: aws:ec2
labels.description: AWS EC2

items.body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

```
$ AWS_PROFILE="cloud" aws --region=us-east-1 ec2 describe-availability-zones --zone-name us-east-1a
{
    "AvailabilityZones": [
        {
            "State": "available",
            "OptInStatus": "opt-in-not-required",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-east-1a",
            "ZoneId": "use1-az4",
            "GroupName": "us-east-1",
            "NetworkBorderGroup": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneType": "availability-zone"
        }
    ]
}
```

```
$ AWS_PROFILE="localstack" aws --endpoint-url=http://localhost:4566 --region=us-east-1 ec2 describe-availability-zones --zone-name us-east-1a
{
    "AvailabilityZones": [
        {
            "State": "available",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-east-1a",
            "ZoneId": "use1-az6"
        },
        {
            "State": "available",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-east-1b",
            "ZoneId": "use1-az1"
        },
        {
            "State": "available",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-east-1c",
            "ZoneId": "use1-az2"
        },
        {
            "State": "available",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-east-1d",
            "ZoneId": "use1-az4"
        },
        {
            "State": "available",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-east-1e",
            "ZoneId": "use1-az3"
        },
        {
            "State": "available",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-east-1f",
            "ZoneId": "use1-az5"
        }
    ]
}
```

### Expected Behavior

```
$ AWS_PROFILE="cloud" aws --region=us-east-1 ec2 describe-availability-zones --zone-name us-east-1a
{
    "AvailabilityZones": [
        {
            "State": "available",
            "OptInStatus": "opt-in-not-required",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-east-1a",
            "ZoneId": "use1-az4",
            "GroupName": "us-east-1",
            "NetworkBorderGroup": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneType": "availability-zone"
        }
    ]
}
```

```
$ AWS_PROFILE="localstack" aws --endpoint-url=http://localhost:4566 --region=us-east-1 ec2 describe-availability-zones --zone-name us-east-1a
{
    "AvailabilityZones": [
        {
            "State": "available",
            "Messages": [],
            "RegionName": "us-east-1",
            "ZoneName": "us-east-1a",
            "ZoneId": "use1-az6"
        }
    ]
}
```

### How are you starting LocalStack?

Custom (please describe below)

### Steps To Reproduce

localstack started with:

DATA_DIR="/tmp/localstack/data" localstack start

### Environment

```markdown
- OS: Ubuntu 20.04 (running in Windows Subsystem for Linux v2)
- LocalStack: 0.12.18.3
```


### Anything else?

Our Terraform configurations use an `aws_availability_zone` data source with the `name` argument in order to look up Zone ID by Zone Name and I first discovered this issue because when running the configuration against our public AWS account(s) this works properly but against localstack the data source returns an error because there are multiple results.  Thus, this is blocking adoption of localstack for developer use in our organization.

items.title: unhandled exception when requirements.txt is missing
items.body:
when running `pip-missing-reqs` command on my project, if no `requirements.txt` is found the execution stops as expected. The output is an unhandled exception tho, which could be catched and returned with a cleaner version

output sample:
```python
> pip-missing-reqs project

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_file.py", line 573, in get_file_content
    with open(url, 'rb') as f:
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'requirements.txt'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/project/bin/pip-missing-reqs", line 8, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pip_check_reqs/find_missing_reqs.py", line 144, in main
    requirements_filename=requirements_filename,
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pip_check_reqs/find_missing_reqs.py", line 63, in find_missing_reqs
    session=PipSession(),
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_file.py", line 151, in parse_requirements
    for parsed_line in parser.parse(filename, constraint):
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_file.py", line 330, in parse
    for line in self._parse_and_recurse(filename, constraint):
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_file.py", line 335, in _parse_and_recurse
    for line in self._parse_file(filename, constraint):
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_file.py", line 369, in _parse_file
    filename, self._session, comes_from=self._comes_from
  File "/Users/user/.local/share/virtualenvs/project/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_file.py", line 577, in get_file_content
    'Could not open requirements file: {}'.format(exc)
pip._internal.exceptions.InstallationError: Could not open requirements file: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'requirements.txt'
```

the output can be cleaned in something like

```python
> pip-missing-reqs project

FileNotFoundError: Cannot find 'requirements.txt' file, please add it in order to detect missing requirements
```

If deemed useful I can try and make a PR when I have the time
